Topic.Title: How many "green jobs" will $529 million buy?

Message.Msg: ...“Oh dear! Oh no! Say it isn't so!...Obama administration had advance warning on Fisker" – Frog boy Oh, dear! Oh no! Say it isn’t so! While your right wing blog sources have already retracted the last bunch of nonsense you posted here about the Saudi terrorist being deported, apparently you chose, instead, to just keep throwing out more of your fictionalized versions of events as you see them. Why not post the other viewpoint of the article, which also included this…people are smart enough to decipher their own versions of the truth without your blatant and pathetic birther/swiftboat versions of events. (From the story)… “Aoife McCarthy, a spokeswoman for the Energy Department, said the June 2010 email was taken out of context. "The document shows that one person at a meeting discussed the possibility that Fisker might not meet a financial commitment" required by the Energy Department, McCarthy said in an email. The department received the needed certification five days later and subsequently made the loan payment, she said. The documents were released Wednesday by the House Oversight and Government Reform committee, which is looking into the federal loan to the troubled car maker. Continuing financial and production problems has led to the lay-off of three-fourths of its workers. White House spokesman Jay Carney accused congressional Republicans of leaking the documents in an effort to embarrass the Obama administration. "The committee's efforts to stoke false controversy by selectively leaking a few out-of-context documents just do not stand up to scrutiny," Carney said Wednesday. A top Energy Department official said the department acted "decisively" to protect taxpayers' interests since Fisker's financial woes became clear nearly two years ago. Nicholas Whitcombe, former acting director of the car loan program, said the department stopped payments to Fisker in June 2011 after the company failed to meet milestones required in the loan agreement. Since then, "the department has continued to communicate with Fisker as it has sought to revise its business plan and achieve profitability," Whitcombe told the committee. The Energy Department is "committed to ensuring that the taxpayers' interests are protected to the maximum extent possible," he added. But Rep. Jim Jordan*, chairman of the Oversight subcommittee on economic growth and regulation, said it is hard to understand why the Energy Department ever thought Fisker was a viable company that should receive taxpayer money. "The Obama administration owes the American taxpayer an explanation as to why this bad loan was made in the first place, and what they are going to do to minimize the loss that taxpayers face," said Jordan, R-Ohio. Rep. Elijah Cummings, D-Md., said the loan program, which has benefited car companies such as Ford, Nissan and Tesla, was exceeding expectations. The Fisker loan represents less than 2 percent of the car-loan program, Cummings and other Democrats said. "There is no evidence that the (Energy) department did anything wrong with this loan," Cummings said. "No evidence that politics played any part in the award to Fisker." – end * Note: Rep. Jim Jordan is a former state wrestling champion elected to the House from the most Republican District in Ohio. He’s also a darling of the far right. He seems to have concerns about taxpayers’ money, (in this case 171 million). Not surprisingly, however, he has no problems with arguing against the Pentagon’s recommendations to save 3 BILLION dollars on tank production, because the tank plant is in his own District. Frog, we’ll be awaiting your next editorial of concern for all of us….something like this…“Oh, dear, Rep. Jordan wants to blow 3 billion dollars when the Pentagon, who should know a bit more about tanks than a grappler turned politician, wants to waste 3 Billion dollars!! In your heart, you know I’m a hypocrite. (Let’s see here…$3,000,000,000 minus $171,000,000 equals 2 Billion, Eight Hundred and Twenty-Nine million worth of hypocrisy.) Ribbit!

Topic.Title: Union entitlements are constraining ATT

Message.Msg: Wilkie, in my time on the job, I was at every major company you can name. Both public and government. In the course of my work, I heard #$%$&moaning as I went about my business. Bitterness is pervasive in any segment of business, whether it's the janitor or a mid-level or above level. I couldn't help overhearing all the griping about everything from "he/she's so incompetent...how did they EVER get promoted" to "I can't wait to get out of this place for________(fill in the blank for various reasons) My conclusion. Very few employes at most levels are dissatisfied with their jobs whether unionized or not. I must have been an exception. Never did I once not want to get up and make the commute to put in my time. That's not to say every fellow employee or manager were people I'd have a beer with after hours, but there weren't many I truly did not care for.

The American people are sick of it. It is a disgrace and you should be ashamed.

Topic.Title: Union entitlements are constraining ATT

Message.Msg: Without union dues, it is very doubtful we would be compensated as well as we are. The politics however, bothers me. Especially the overwhelming financial contributions that finds its way to a certain political party. Other than that, I have sat at grievances that saved jobs, recouped back pay or other monetary disputes, settled sexual harassment situations, unfair overtime procedures and so many union/management contractual violations that I can't even remember the specifics. We have to part ways on the topic of union or union-free work environs. So while there are drawbacks to a union shop, this can be said. No union member can be let go on the whim of a boss. Just that simple protection validates unions. Now public unions. That's a whole different matter...

Message.Msg: I think we all have a pretty clear picture of the drill. froggy spends his morning consuming large amounts of media. It's likely he is unable to concentrate on anything substantive for very long so he bounces from CNN to Fox to thumbing through copious amounts of largely redundant "print" media. When he has finished consuming, it is time to regurgitate. He chooses a couple of items to cut and paste, puts nice little bullets on them so that they look like they could be products of original thought and posts them on Yahoo message boards. Cutting and pasting takes much of froggy's afternoon. I suppose that there is also a lot of distracted upping and downing for important tasks like seeing if the mailman has come yet, whether anything has mysteriously appeared in the refrigerator since last time he looked, etc., and whether that lump on his face is growing or if it is the same size it was 25 minutes ago. And for his significant contribution to society, we pay for his medical care and keep a SS check coming to him every month. Waste upon waste.

Message.Title: Has congress finally gone too far?
Message.Msg: I don't know about you, but I love my Obama phone. I love my high tech smart phone. I love the free text messaging, the camera and the 100 free minutes. I loved the fact that the government made it so easy for me and my 6 million friends to get this wonderful service regardless of our eligibility. And now I find out that there are 50 members in congress who are trying to take away my free phone. Where is their compassion? Where is their sense of fairness? How many poor children are going to go to bed sad when they can't get their text messages or pictures of their "besties"? Please call your congress person now, and tell them not to vote to cut off my free phone service. Thanks this is real important. "In your heart you know he is right." The Frogg

Topic.Title: Union entitlements are constraining ATT

Message.Msg: Well Whop, here is what the acronym stands for: Order of Repeatermen and Tollboard Testmen. The ORTT personnel were very specialized at one time. Their genesis goes back to when Ma Bell used smoke signals and tin cans attached to rope to communicate. Just kidding Whop. It was a very small unionized part of the Bell System that probably has gone the way of ancient analog technology. I'm not sure if they are still representing members, as they probably merged with the CWA. The contracts were negotiated separately from the much bigger CWA and had basically the same benefits. The main difference was dues. ORTT paid about 75% less than our CWA brothers. I was proud to serve as a steward and will never forget the occasional battles we had with management.

Topic.Title: Union entitlements are constraining ATT

Topic.Title: Union entitlements are constraining ATT

Message.Msg: Dave I hate to guess at your age, but I was with AT&T/SWBT for 30 years and don't remember having that in the Oklahoma area. It's an interesting part of history. Before I retired from Installation/Repair 6 months ago, management had done away with so many jobs that we were doing more and more duties. In smaller towns they were about to start having us do our own Central Office wiring, that was when I said enough is enough. We had already lost our supplies attendants who made sure we were stocked and inventory was maintained. They were expecting productivity to increase but didn't give us credit for the work. Not to be offensive to anyone, but I blamed the union for letting it happen. Nobody would put their foot down and say NO_WAY! The word SAFETY got lost in the books somewhere, and we were expected to do 14 hours of work in 8 hours. All of that pressure to be more productive is why I believe in the stock today. T is weeding out the old slow farts and highering younger high producing ones. You and worked when Safety was first, Quality was second and Productivity was third. The AT&T of today has swapped Safety for Productivity. And it appears to be in all of the phone companies. I've talked to Verizon and Sprint technicians that are going thru the same thing.

Topic.Title: Union entitlements are constraining ATT

Message.Msg: Beau, times have changed and T is not what it used to be. Regardless, it still offers a lot to middle class workers that has pretty good job security. Maybe not new-hires, but once you rack up some years, your in to stay unless you don't follow the rules. You know what I mean. Tardiness, absences, stretching coffee breaks, etc. You are so right about how making a good wage leads to excess spending. I did as you did. Maxed the 401 plus supplemental and still contributed to a self-directed IRA every year. It's really comes down to this. It isn't necessarily how much you make...it's what you do with what you earn that matters. Maybe someone else said that before, but I lay claim to it. As for T stock price? I'm not overly concerned about it. The dividends allow me to pay for the things that are important to my family. The stock price will be what it is.

Topic.Title: Union entitlements are constraining ATT

Message.Msg: I can't argue that. The company is not what it used to be my friend. I can only comment on what I experienced. I am fortunate to have a FCC license, so I had the opportunity to do just about everything you can think of. Ship to Shore radio, every form of local and long distance carrier (except "N" which was being phased out). I climbed poles, worked manholes spliced, provisioned, trouble shot just about any type of circuit you can name, worked the frames, b-boxes, fiber huts, T1to T3, you name it, I had my hands on it. Inside and in the field. I even had access to all the digital switches (through a back door program) to check translations, etc., even though i wasn't a switchman. I loved what I did. The only thing I didn't do was tech support. I still stay in touch with my former PCO and I've heard all about the new T from the folks that are still there. Needless to say, they don't have the same opinion that I have. But you know how it goes. It's a paycheck. And it's a damn good paycheck, thanks to all the bargaining that got the members to this point from many years ago. P.S. I once sat as an observer/negotiator at a contract renewal. Now THAT was an interesting experience!

Topic.Title: Has congress finally gone too far?

Message.Msg: ...Hey, Frog boy…back so soon? This time with the “Obama Phone”???? Wow, talk about desperation…must be slim pickens for your side, huh? Man, you’ve got multiple lies goin’ on, they all get rejected, but you keep on crankin’ them out. Please fill us in on why everybody’s laughin’ at Glen Beck’s latest conspiracy theory about Boston, yet you brought it here as though it was the gospel truth? And then you disappear like a cheap dinner guest in a restaurant when the check arrives. If you are ever to be taken seriously, when you’re way-out-there-wrong, you need to admit it and apologize…oh, that’s right, you speak for the folks with the monopoly on taking personal responsibility for your actions…(hmmm, the word hypocrisy has already been bandied about today)…like intentionally lying as your only strategy. In the immortal words of Ricky Ricardo, “Froggie, I’m home…and you’ve got some splainin’ to do!!!!” “It’s been commonly called the Obama Phone, but that’s an urban legend as free cell phones originated under President Bush. The original Lifeline phone program started back in the 80’s under Ronald Reagan. And it’s not paid for by the taxpayers, but through a fee assessed to the telecoms.” So, frog boy, they aren't coming after your guns, and they're not coming after your phone...but the folks in white with the butterfly nets may be coming after you. You are a pathetic liar. You’re not a frog at all…just that green algae, more appropriately known as pond #$%$. Ribbit!

Topic.Title: Union entitlements are constraining ATT

Message.Msg: No vendetta.. Just facts. Great for those that got nice packages.. As you can see those are gone. Happening all over multiple industries. Its just over because union entities cant compete with nonunion ones due to the inefficiencies unions are able to employ. I saw it running a semiconductor fab in ohio years ago. You need 3 or 4 people to do a job a cross trained individual could do easily. Not lean 6 sigma by a long shot. Sorry I didnt take the test to work for T. I took those while getting my EE and Industrial Mgt degrees. Passed a couple of them but thanks for your concern. Anyway T is nothing but a divi stock now. Fees too high and I wonder why that might be? Peace The Capper.

Message.Msg: ...Frog-like postings (except this one is true…finally, some credibility for the GOP) John Boehner's Future Son-in-law Once Busted for Pot (cue “cry me a river” from the tanning bed, Joe Cocker version) by Kristen Butler, UPI “Speaker of the House John Boehner may have something new to cry about -- his daughter's impending marriage. Lindsay Boehner, who lives in Hollywood, Florida, is engaged to Jamaica-born Dominic Lakhan, and records show they're set to tie the knot May 5, reports N. Y. Daily News. Lakhan was pulled over in 2006 for a traffic violation, and a Pembroke Pines, FL. police officer found *four grams of marijuana in his ashtray and "observed in plain view a 16 oz. Natural Light beer can opened in the driver door," according to a police report. "Officer also detected the odor of burnt #$%$ emitting from the interior of the vehicle." Lakhan, 38, admitted to possessing the marijuana “for personal use” and was charged with misdemeanor possession. Records also show Lakhan was charged with possession of an open container of alcohol while driving back in 2003. Republican House Speaker John Boehner is a social conservative, widely known to be a religious Catholic and firmly against marijuana legalization. “ – end of UPI story *that’s a seventh of an ounce…no sweat in a de-crim state, but if you’ve got four grams in the ashtray of your car…well, I’d just ask what the traffic violation he originally got pulled over for was…levitating himself out of John Boehner’s driveway? Message.Title: Things are solid,great div and earnings,
Message.Msg: The board of directors of AT&T Inc. (NYSE:T) today declared a quarterly dividend of $0.45 a share on the company’s common shares. The dividend is payable on May 1, 2013, to stockholders of record at the close of business on April 10, 2013. At the same time, the board authorized the repurchase of up to 300 million shares, representing approximately 5.5 percent of AT&T common shares outstanding, with no expiration date. This authorization is in addition to two other 300 million share repurchase authorizations approved by the board of directors in December 2010 and July 2012. The company completed repurchases under the December 2010 share authorization last year.
